Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Collaborative Research: Keyphrase Extraction in Document Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: Keyphrases for a document concisely describe the document using a small set of phrases (i.e., sequences of contiguous words in a document). For example, the keyphrases "social networks" and "interest targeting" quickly provide us with a high-level topic description (i.e., a summary) of a document focused on targeting interest for recommending services such as products and news to users, in the context of social networks. Given today's very large collections of documents, these keyphrases are extremely important not only for summarizing a document, but also for the search and retrieval of relevant information. However, keyphrases are not always available directly. Instead, they need to be gleaned from the many details in documents. This project addresses the problem of automatic keyphrase extraction from research papers, which are enablers of the sharing and dissemination of scientific discoveries. The goal of the project is to explore accurate approaches that automatically discover and extract keyphrases in documents, using document networks, which will help users handle and digest more information in less time during these "big data" times. Educationally, this research will involve training of both graduate and undergraduate students in the active area of research of keyphrase extraction, which has high impact in many real-world applications such as online advertising, document categorization, recommendation, and summarization, Web search and discovery, and topic tracking in newswire. Although much research to date has been done on automatic keyphrase extraction, no previous approaches have captured the impact of documents on one another via the citation relation that connects documents in a network. This project will investigate models that take into consideration the linkage between citing and cited documents in a document network and will explore various qualitative and quantitative aspects of the question: "What are the key phrases or concepts in a document?" Scalable iterative algorithms will be designed and developed that capture different aspects of documents (e.g., topics or concepts), as well as the impact of one document on another (e.g., influence or topic evolution) in a document network. The results of this research will have a direct pipeline to the CiteSeerX digital library (http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu). The software, tools, and benchmark datasets developed during the course of this project will be broadly disseminated via the project website (http://people.cs.ksu.edu/~ccaragea/keyphrases.html). All findings will be shared to the research community through publications in academic journals and presented in Information Retrieval, Text Mining and Natural Language Processing conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the large and growing amounts of scientific data, researchers are exposed to large numbers of research papers. The most important parts or concepts of a paper are not always readily available, but they need to be extracted from the content of each paper. Keyword extraction, defined as the problem of automatically extracting the important words or concepts of a text, is central to dealing with the overwhelming amounts of information available in these papers. The goal of this project is to explore robust and accurate approaches that uncover the most important parts of documents to allow for efficient information processing. In particular, this project investigates models that take into consideration the linkage between citing and cited documents in a document network and explores various qualitative and quantitative aspects of the question: What are the keywords or concepts in a document? The proposed models are based on novel supervised and unsupervised approaches.

This project led to a suite of key research advances. First, our work was the first to exploit citation network information for keyphrase extraction and showed remarkable improvements in performance over strong baselines in both supervised and unsupervised settings. We designed unsupervised graph-based algorithms that incorporate evidence from multiple sources (citation contexts and document content, position information of words in documents, and the contextual embeddings of words in documents) in a flexible manner. We also presented supervised approaches to keyphrase extraction from research papers, and proposed novel features extracted from citation contexts that showed improvements in performance over supervised and unsupervised baselines. Second, we created gold-standard datasets of research papers and their associated citation networks, using directly the CiteSeerx database. Finally, we investigated the role of keyphrases in several downstream applications such as venue classification for scholarly documents, topic classification, and document search and crawling. Our research findings have been widely disseminated in top research venues in AI, NLP, and Web. Such venues in which we published our results include: AAAI, ACL, EMNLP, and WWW. Along with our collaborators from Pennsylvania State University, we organized several workshops on “Scholarly Big Data: AI Perspectives, Challenges and Ideas” co-located with top AI conferences.

Results from this project have been incorporated into a series of lectures, seminar presentations and invited talks. Research components have been critical parts of undergraduate and graduate courses that have impacted undergraduate and graduate students. Further, this project has supported outreach - through lectures and invited seminars, to K-12 students.
